newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: FEATURE-Investors await new Pakistan government.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE-Investors await new Pakistan government.

text.p: The advent of a pro-business government after Pakistan's election next Monday could prompt renewed direct foreign investment in the nation's battered economy, analysts say.

"If the elections bring a pro-business government which implements a privatisation programme and gives economic incentives, the present downward trend in portfolio and direct investment will be halted in the next financial year (1997/98 July-June)," said analyst Nadeem Naqvi.
Sales of state assets would spur private sector investment in expansion plans and stimulate the energy sector, said Naqvi, head of Research of International Asset Management Co Ltd.
"A turnaround in the textile sector, specially the value-added spinning sector, is also expected, boosting investment prospects in Pakistan," Naqvi said.

An Asian diplomat said major concerns for foreign investors were political instability -- four Pakistani governments have been dismissed on corruption charges since martial law ended in 1985 -- law and order, and inconsistent economic policies.
"If Pakistan manages to overcome these problems, it would boost investors' confidence," he said.
The tax-packed 1996/97 budget, economic woes and political uncertainty have hurt the overall investment climate.
Naqvi said the June budget had had a recessionary impact. "Foreign and local investors started pulling out investments after the budget was announced," he said.

"The industry outlook changed dramatically as earnings of industrial units were downgraded by foreigners after the announcement of the tax-laden budget. As political uncertainty increased, they further discounted Pakistan," he said.
Money flowed out of portfolios faster than it flowed in during the first half of 1996/97 as foreign investors siphoned 7.362 billion rupees out of the Pakistani market.
Direct investment flows plummeted as major projects were shelved or delayed by political crises and economic problems.
President Farooq Leghari's November 5 removal of Benazir Bhutto's government on disputed charges of corruption and nepotism had further dampened foreign investors' interest.
Naqvi said direct foreign investment was likely to reach $500-$600 million in 1996/97, against $1.1 billion in 1995/96.

According to the Board of Investment, foreign direct and portfolio investment totalled $1.295 billion in 1995/96 compared to $670 million in 1994/95. Britain, the United States and Japan were the top three sources of investment.
Mahmood Ahmed, vice-president of the Federation of Pakistan Chambers of Commerce and Industry, said investments had been at a near standstill for the past few months.
"Where there were projects, they have either been stopped or delayed. Only 20 percent of the memoranda of understanding signed by the previous government have been honoured," he said.
Nor was any attempt being made to help floundering firms. "There are no efforts to revive sick industry as the caretaker government has a short-term agenda," he said.

Investors have grown wary of inconsistent government policies. "For example, the concessions given for setting up industries in industrial zones were withdrawn just 10 months after the announcement," he said.
Naqvi said there had been a "mini-flight" of capital by local investors over the past eight months because of fears of rupee devaluation and high taxes.
A foreign fund manager said the decline in portfolio investment in Pakistan had been aggravated by a general fall from favour of emerging markets, especially in South Asia.
"The U.S. market is so strong, there is no point in investors coming here," he said, adding that Pakistan's economic troubles also had an impact on the inflow.

"Pakistan's balance of payments has been exposed...June to December payments were financed through reserve funds and they plummeted to $400 million from $2 billion," said the fund manager, who asked not to be named.
"Investors were hit by the sharp falls in the currency last year which eroded 17 percent against the dollar. There still is a currency risk of 15 to 20 percent in 1997," he added.
